        <a href="/heritage-sites/baroque-bungalow-on-raised-footings-early-1900s" class="site-name">Baroque Bungalow on raised footings (early 1900s)</a>
        <div class="site-buttons">

            </svg> </a><a class="site-button" href="/heritage-sites/baroque-bungalow-on-raised-footings-early-1900s"><div>Learn More</div>
            <div>→</div></a>
        </div>
        <p class="site-description">
          House No. 9, Buckley Road, is a preserved bungalow built in the early
          1900s. Featuring Baroque and Classical designs, it stands on raised
          footings. It was awarded URA conservation status in 2008.
        </p>
      </div>
    </div>
    <div role="listitem">

            </svg> </a><a class="site-button" href="/heritage-sites/beulah-house"><div>Learn More</div>
            <div>→</div></a>
        </div>
        <p class="site-description">
          The bungalow with its distinctive conical turret roof, once an eye
          clinic, was purchased by Life Bible-Presbyterian Church in 1990.
          Gazetted for conservation in 2003, it retains its earthy tones,
          contrasting with nearby high-rise buildings, marking Gilstead Road's
          entrance.
        </p>
      </div>
    </div>

            <div>→</div></a>
        </div>
        <p class="site-description">
          The Malcolm Road Colonial Bungalows, built around 1925 for British
          civil servants, feature 30 black-and-white homes on a scenic,
          tree-lined road. Now managed by the Singapore Land Authority, they
          retain a serene atmosphere.
        </p>
      </div>
    </div>
    <div role="listitem">

            <div>→</div></a>
        </div>
        <p class="site-description">
          Singapore's only Heritage lychee tree, standing 18 meters tall, has
          been safeguarded by a steel structure since 2017. Over 100 years old,
          it resides in the Novena neighborhood's Mount Rosie.
        </p>
      </div>
    </div>
    <div role="listitem">

            </svg> </a><a class="site-button" href="/heritage-sites/westbourne-mansion"><div>Learn More</div>
            <div>→</div></a>
        </div>
        <p class="site-description">
          Built in 1927 for Dr. Yin Suat Chuan (father of Saint author Leslie
          Charteris), the conservation-listed "Westbourne" mansion at 25
          Gilstead Road has been adaptively reused by various organizations
          including the Cerebral Palsy Alliance Singapore and kindergartens.
          Notable former residents include Dr. J.S. Webster, who established
          Singapore's St John's Ambulance division.
        </p>
      </div>
    </div>
